reviewText:
SIne Mora is a rare game of it’s kind. In a generation overwhelmed by FPSes and RPGs it's very hard to make a good Shoot 'em Up which appeals to both fans of the genre and one-time players. The developers tried to make a game that balances between casual and hardcore shmup game experience. How they managed it, is a matter of an other question.

Yes, you can pick up Sine Mora and play it without having played any shmups ever before. And yes, you can have fun with it if you are a veteran player. Sadly, you can side in either of the two groups, the fun will start to fade away quite quickly. The game tries to please both sides at the same time which, in some cases is impossible. Sometimes it tries to cut corners with inconsistent bullet pattern and difficult hit detection to please the casual fan base, in other times it gets so difficult that a one-time player will probably quit after a couple of fails. It's a balance often Sine Mora just can't get right.

The game introduces an interesting time based mechanism. You and your planes don't have any health; instead you get a time meter constantly counting down. Once it hits zero, you are dead. To keep the meter running you have to shoot down enemy planes and vehicles which will add time to the counter. It's really interesting and the devs should be praised for coming up with this unique approach which actually works really well.

The story is something that bugs me. Sine Mora introduces a world, background story, multiple timelines and several characters that would be too much even for a game with a dozen-hour length of game play. But no, our game’s campaign lasts around 2 to 3 hours (!), which is frankly, disappointing. You will never get the idea of the story as it's overly complicated for a game of this magnitude. To make the matter worse, different characters are introduced every 20 minutes and that's where you lose any interest of understanding the underlying story. Just give me the next Boss and let's get on with it! And the game does. There are huge boss battles in every 15 minutes, which on normal are pieces of cakes, but on harder difficulty give players a hell lot of trouble.

If there's one thing in which the game excels it's the graphics department. It looks absolutely astonishingly beautiful, for its genre it is over the top. The environment is colorful, detailed and alive. Levels are varied and vivid, and you have to really look hard for graphic letdowns in the game. Audio-wise the game keeps up the pace with an excellently composed soundtrack that is worth listening to. The sound effects sometimes feel weird and weak, but you can get used to it. The voice over is where the game really lets us down. For one thing, there's no English voice track. For whatever reason the devs decided to include only the original, Hungarian voice over. For those who can't speak the language, you won't miss a thing. Voice actors feel unmotivated and rather reading than acting their scripts. Also, it is littered with Hungarian trash language that sometimes feel uncomfortably awkward.

After breezing through the short and puzzled campaign for a casual gamer there's sadly not much to do further. All the other game modes where you can change your planes and pilots are for veteran and experienced shmup players. If you are a one time player you can give it a shot, but be prepared to fail many times. Some of the bosses and levels can get so difficult that it will frustrate even the most talented players. And this isn't because of the lack of skills from the player, but rather the aforementioned flaws: inconsistent bullet patterns and odd hit detection.

Sine Mora tries so hard to please everyone that it fails to please many. Every gamer hard-core shmup player or casual can have a shot at this beautifully confusing piece, but after a couple of hours we move on with ambiguous feelings.

Rating: 61/100; Replay Value: 2/5; To Beat: 2.5 hours (campaign); Played on: normal.

Sine Mora is a shoot 'em up from Digital Reality, the company that gave us games such as Imperium Galactica, Haegemonia and Platoon. I guess Sine Mora is one of the first indie games they have developed so far - an attempt at something different with lower production costs and a now not very common genre.

Do note that this game is very difficult! Even on normal difficulty setting it is easy to perish and boss battles do not make it easier. There is a constant swarm of enemies and as typical of the genre the longer you survive without being hit the stronger you can become by picking up all the various power-ups lying about.

Graphics are decent and there are cutscenes incorporated in the narrative that make the game look even more fantastic. I liked how the camera focused on the plane as we were transitioning from one place to another. The story takes place in a fictitious world and it is a tale of, mainly, revenge. Its steampunk approach renders it a unique atmosphere - even more interesting is the Hungarian audio that - per default - you will hear.

Greater difficulty levels and various story modes available make Sine Mora a long-lasting experience. If you like the genre and you are in for some challenge pick this one up

reviewText:
Fighter planes, anthro characters, voice-work entirely in Hungarian. Huh.

Time travel is one of the biggest cliches in science fiction and is often a highly convenient plot mechanism to force both any deus ex machina the author wants while simultaneously causing enough paradoxical crap going down so that people will have to choice but to make the story a subject of discussion and debate. It's cheap writing and easy to drag to a solipsist extreme.
Thankfully, Sina Mora doesn't fall into that trap. Though you mostly play as the race of time-traveling Enkies fighting against the Empire that enslaved them in order to harness their powers, the time travel aspect of the game is tastefully and responsibly handled.

The models, backgrounds, and visuals are absolutely stunning and run extremely well on even a poor rig; it's a wonder this game's budget somehow wasn't three times bigger in order to achieve this level of eye-candy. Sound effects and voice-acting are high-quality too, although a choice to have voicing done entirely in the Hungarian language might befuddle those who aren't in on this apparent trend of considering it to be a scifi-friendly language (what).

The story is mostly told through white-on-black text at the beginnings and endings of each level, with differences in the higher difficulty, and through the encyclopedia unlocked after beating the game once. Actual in-level story exposition is somewhat limited and may confuse people expecting a clear story they won't have to think through much. You'll have to play through the game more than once to get the full picture on things, especially since details on the internet are sparse due to the small audience, and even then, the story is a rather depressing one that is more about the last-stand of a dead nation and a corrupt ex-soldier out to avenge his son, rather than the admirable and effective heroics of bizzarely competent freedom fighters who unquestionably hold the higher ground.

And that's where Sine Mora wins me over: they don't pull the time-travel ♥♥♥♥ when someone you like dies. They don't give a name and face to the Empire you're fighting against; they don't caricaturize the horror you're up against. You are told from the start that you are fighting in a doomed war against a massive and anonymous machine that has already wiped out your people past any hope of a meaningful resurgence, and are left with nothing but a gruesome description of what has become of those people.

Despite time travel being the easiest out in any fictional work, this game's story instills you with a crushed hopelessness. Under no delusions of grandeur or heroism, you charge out onto your Endless War. The Enky calendar is one that counts down, and you personify it in your repeated terrorizing throughout the various years you skip to, becoming a demon to those who now live in comfort due to the unwilling sacrifices forced upon your ancestors and descendants.

reviewText:
This turned out to be a really visually interesting arcadey shmup, and I had a blast just looking at and discovering things for the first time. It's incredibly well designed and tight with a great depth of options for replay value, it's just such a damn shame that it's so short on levels and content.

Highlights
The focus and budget on Sine Mora clearly went into the set designs, which are a really compelling mix of 3D environments played from a 2D point of view. The world is varied and interesting, and the art style is sharp but still arcadey enough to be mostly upbeat and fun. The enemies are all different and while they mostly play the same (take out section X -> move forward or flip angles and take on section Y -> survive through bullet-hell section Z to defeat the enemy) there are a few unique sections where the screen will rotate and it's about accomplishing various objectives, or you'll be dodging more than shooting, or vice versa. These all help to mix the gameplay up and make the enemies interesting.

The other thing that makes this title shine is the story elements and good writing everywhere. Every character has a well introduced backstory, and not just to give them depth, it also fits them into the story. There's a fantastic encyclopaedia available in the menu screens that helps you understand each aspect of the world and history of the characters more, and the introduction to enemies is very interesting in game. It feels more mature than you'd expect from a typical shmup, especially one with an arcade style gameplay like this.

Mistakes and Annoyances
By far the biggest problem with Sine Mora is the lack of content. Clearly it was never intended to be longer than a few hours, and the focus went into the beauty and design of those levels, which shows. But despite the replay value offered by multiple characters, aircraft, unlockables and different gaming modes like score attack and arcade, it's just boring and repetitive after more than a few hours. If you're not a completionist, a die-hard shmup fan, or both then you're unlikely to have reason to play the story more than once or twice.

The other failure or complaint is that shmup fans typically want to strive for high scores and competitive speedruns, etc. They're the type of gamers who expect more than just a score attack, and get annoyed at things like random score multipliers, random powerups and things that take away from the real competitive aspect of the game. Sine Mora seems to have tried to appease new players and die-hard shmup fans and has failed on the latter as a result.

Recommendations
Available for £7.99/9.99€/$9.99 on Steam and while it's pretty short, it's still fair value when compared to competitors like Jamestown and Raiden III Digital Edition at the same price. When it's on sale, in my opinion it's probably the best option on Steam for a modern entry level shmup for someone like me who isn't heavily into the genre but wants to give something more casual like this a try.

reviewText:
AUDIO: Atmospheric                                                       AESTHETIC: Gorgeous
MEMORABILITY: Gorgeous                                           WORTH: Light Discount

PROS: This game is eyecandy, writ large. It proves that Shoot 'Em Ups don't need to be against a flat-panning or blank backgrounds, but can instead tell a story within lush landscapes. The game is an excellent toe in the water for people interested in Bullet Hell, as it has the elements of one at a slower pace. I personally really enjoyed the weight of the plane, rather than feeling like it was a cursor. This game gets a lot of flack for being difficult, as well as many other negative comments I downright balk at-- I simply don't see where they're coming from.

CONS: I've dealt with some compatibility issues running in the past. If you're a seasoned veteran of shmups, you're going to find the slow pace maddening. A fair amount of the story is only available in the encyclopedia and the second playthrough, making is a little confusing upon initial approach. The big problem: Broken achievements. To earn some, you must use a character unavailable in this version. Real heart-breaker.

OVERALL:  I don't know about you, but Sine Mora is nirvana for me. It's not high-strung or jaw-dropping. It's a scenic, entertaining experience that I've enjoyed playing and replaying. I'd love to give a 10/10 if the achievements are ever fixed!

SCORE: 9/10
Edit: I have made it recently a personal policy to not recommend games with broken achievements. reviewText:
Gorgeous looking game with confusing storytelling. The voice overs are Japanese (I'm sure they can be switched to English, but I like to play games in the way they're intended) and the text is English so you have to pay attention to the subtitles in order to understand at least something of the story. But even then, it's extremely confusing, with all the different characters and the constant switching between them. It seems rather deep for a shoot 'em up, and who knows... it might actually be true.

Sine Mora is a shoot 'em up, llke many other games out there. But it uses a time aspect, meaning you get extra time for killing enemies. Get hit and you'll lose time. It's a solid idea that works very well. You can also slow time down to guide your aircraft between tens of bullets safely. So, as you can see, it mixes things up a little.

Enemies will drop points, subweapons and weapon upgrades as well.

The environments are beautiful with some nice little touches and the game offers plenty of boss battles. It also runs at a solid 60FPS which helps add to the immersion of it all.

But it's short. I finished it in 2,5 hours. After that you can try and go for the achievements. The achievement system is actually something I'd like to see more often in games. Here, you have to complete several objectives before getting awarded an achievement. So there's a high replay value if you're into that sort of stuff.

If you like shoot 'em ups you should get this no matter what.
But if you enjoy them from time to time I suggest waiting for a price drop. The price is a bit steep and it's still on the short side.

reviewText:
For four dollars, Sine Mora is a game list inflating impulse buy. Given the choice, I would remove this game from my collection and write off the money as an experience worth paying for. If Steam had a 'rent' option, this game would be good for one to two nights of play, based on my experiences.

Positive aspects:
+ Graphical style
+ Interesting character/ship/weapon combination grid
+ Standard schmup gameplay
+ Responsive controls

Negative aspects:
- Buggy graphics cause distracting glitches
- Buggy gameplay causes unfair deaths
- Fast forward feature slows framerate and stops sound, but doesn't fast forward, making the necessary replays to perfect this sort of game unnecessarily tedious, especially with the many scripted scenes players are forced to sit through
- Awkward pacing between gameplay and scripted scenes
- Not much information about selectable weapons and ships

If these bugs weren't present, Sine Mora would be an excellent game at the price asked. As it is now, it was worth a couple hours of my time before I couldn't ignore how inconvenient it is to play, and I was hoping to spend hours mastering a new schmup. I do not recommend buying this game without downloading the demo to test for bugs. If things function as expected, or you can ignore the pacing & technical issues, then it's worth the price.

However, I do not recommend this game to anybody who doesn't have the time or dedication to try inexpensive games before buying, and who doesn't have the time or patience to deal with the problematic aspects of the game. The cost of purchase is not worth the risk of experiencing the game breaking bugs that I experienced.

reviewText:
Before I kick off, let me just say this: I do not play shoot-em-ups or bullet hell games on a regular basis. Saying that I represent the target audience would be optimistic at best, and I appreciate that some of the features in Sine Mora that annoy me are probably what the target audience likes. I only bought the game because it was on heavy discount and I figured I might be in for a pleasant surprise.

Let's start with the biggest plus: Sine Mora looks great, with cartoonish 3D graphics and wonderful backgrounds and awesome boss enemies. The world is vibrant with all manners of details, which makes it nice to look at, but unfortunately I often encountered severe problems with perceiving depth: it was difficult to tell when an enemy was within line of fire or just off to the side depth-wise, a situation made more confusing by some enemies you can engage even though they are far in the background. The edges of certain levels are ridiculously difficult to identify because of their depth curvature, which is exacerbated by the fact that colliding with a wall kills you. What is this, Silver Surfer on the NES? Avoiding walls and projectiles is particularly difficult on the awfully twitchy keyboard controls, so much so that I would never have beaten the game without a controller. Other than these issues, the game is fairly challenging but far from impossible on normal difficulty, although it thinks nothing of throwing a couple of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t deaths your way whenever it thinks it can get away with it.

Apart from the wonky perspectives and useless keyboard controls, which are frustrating enough for me not to recommend the game, I suppose Sine Mora is solid enough. There is no health bar; instead you have a set time in which to reach the next checkpoint, and getting hit reduces that time whilst dispatching enemies increases it, which I thought was actually quite a fine and innovative mechanism. I only wish it had been stuck to a better game.

The story is a bit difficult to keep track of, and it seems to me that it sets off to tell too much in too complex a manner in too little time, but this is the kind of game that people are probably going to play and replay in hopes of high scores, so they should be able to soak up the plot well enough, I suppose.

reviewText:
I started Sine Mora as a casual game to play between “long games” since according to online sources you can get through it in about 2 hours. I don’t think so. I’ve played the game about 2 and a half hours and there is no way I’m ever going to finish it. Not because the game is bad, but because it’s too hard. The “easy” mode still fills the screen with enemy fire and I don’t see how a casual player can get through it without retrying a million times. I thought maybe I could get a few achievements out of the game at least, but I only got 2 out of the 12 possible and don’t think I’ll be able to advance further.

The first thing you’ll notice on starting the game is that it’s in a different language, with subtitles. I’m not sure what language it is but it sounds Eastern European. The story is difficult to understand since it deals with time travel, revenge, and some sort of interplanetary rebellion. The narration that starts each mission is mostly philosophical and adds very little to the story, just the speaker’s “motivation.” You also constantly switch characters as you play and they all have different backstories. Some of the people are ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s too, so I wouldn’t call them the “good guys” either. From what I understood, you're playing the members of a rebel team trying to cause damage to the Empire in 2 different time lines (constantly switching between past and present).

Sine Mora is a side scrolling “bullet hell” game where you control a small aircraft usually traveling from left to right across the screen with lots of little ships flying past and shooting at you. There is a lot of variety in the game, planes, helicopters, boats, and even a lot of underwater combat. Every level seems to have multiple large boss enemies with various weak points that need to be blasted off. Similar to the old Raiden games (Super Nintendo) you collect weapon power-ups and screen clearing “bombs” (every character has a different secondary weapon, not always bombs). You do not have “lives” or a health bar, but instead you have a timer counting down to zero. When you kill an enemy you get a few seconds added to the clock, and if you take damage you lose some time. Of course when you reach zero you die. One annoying thing is that your weapon power-ups can be lost (they fly off when you take damage) and you have to chase after them before they leave the screen. You do have one big advantage though; all of your characters can slow down time (limited use) and use this to dodge the lasers and missiles flying at you.

Pros:
-Sine Mora is actually pretty fun in the beginning (before it gets insanely hard).
-Surprisingly good graphics for a game that’s only 300 megabytes. The visuals / bosses seriously look amazing.
-Many boss battles, which are great in shoot-em up games.

Cons:
-Totally unfairly unbeatably hard by the end. And I was playing “amateur” mode. I’m sure some people can do it, but they’re probably the guys doing 100 hit combos in Marvel vs Capcom. I lost a lot of weapon power-ups to enemy fire and then lost even more when I chased after them trying to collect what I lost. There are also a bunch of instant kill shots that you don’t get warned about.
-The steam achievements are “chained.” You can’t get the later ones without getting the early ones. For example, Airman, Sargent, Lieutenant, Major, etc. You can’t get Major without getting Lieutenant and I couldn’t even unlock Sargent! Each achievement has a SET of requirements to unlock. So it’s not like “Kill this boss.” To unlock 1 achievement might require: 1) Crash 15 times 2) Get 100% accuracy on any level 3) kill 100 ships, etc. I was stuck on a requirement to finish any level with A rank. Best I could get was a D rank…
-The story is practically incomprehensible at times. This might be because it’s in another language and is “narrated” to you with heavy character bias.
-Some of the later bosses will make you tear your hair out. They fill the screen with 100000000 fast moving bullets and half of them are homing. One of them knocked me out in about 20 seconds every time and it wasn’t until my 10th try that I realized he was actually reflecting my bullets back at me (so fast they’re almost invisible). The time slowing power might be enough to get through a boss fight, but each level seems to have at least 2 bosses.

Overall I do not recommend the game to casual players and only to people who have awesome hand eye coordination. It’s a shame too because I really liked the graphics and shoot-em up in the beginning of the game. The difficulty killed it for me though. I can’t say I enjoyed the experience overall.

reviewText:
In every facet of its design Sine Mora exudes excellence. Considerably well polished from presentation to gameplay, it tells a surprisingly engaging tale of a father's unremitting resolve to take revenge for the death of his son, and takes itself very seriously with mass genocide, physical abuse, and suicide all sharing a place in the unflinching narrative. Even if the plot occasionally becomes convoluted, there is so much conviction in every line of script that it almost didn't matter what was being said. I found it fascinating, and though it is entirely possible to skip straight to the action, those wanting for something more substantial should find plenty to keep them occupied.

A side-scrolling shooter is only as good as its gameplay though, and once again Grasshopper Manufacture outdoes itself. Contrary to my expectations of Ikaruga like color swapping, Sine Mora is an entirely new breed of bullet-hell centered around time. Your life is literally dictated as seconds on the clock, and with each enemy you kill that time is extended. Inversely getting hit reduces it, and thus the frenzied back and forth between racing through levels and sending as many enemies to their grave as possible is born.

I've never pretended to be good at this style of game, but Sine Mora strikes a perfect balance between the constant insanity of bullets and giving you the control needed to survive them. In contrast to just about everything similar I have played, there was never a point that I felt overwhelmed or unable to continue, and it is for that very reason that I would whole wholeheartedly recommend those interested in bullet-hell games start here. It isn't an easy game by any stretch, but completing it is certainly achievable for both veterans and novices alike (the former will find plenty of challenge in the higher difficulty level, score challenges, and multiple ranks to shoot for).

It only takes one look at Sine Mora in motion to see it is a downright gorgeous game, but more impressive than even the great texture, lighting and particle effects is the fantastically creative steampunk art direction. Each level is taken up in large part by incredible boss battles the design of which only become more involved and more impressive in scale as they go on, reminding me of everything from The Matrix to Porco Rosso. I rarely bother with concept or unlockable artwork, but I was actually disappointed there was none to be found here. I do wish they had done away with the letterbox framing, but otherwise I was simply awestruck at the visuals and have no doubt that other games will be compared to them for a long time to come.

Grasshopper Games diverse and bizarre catalog is more often than not know for offering quirky yet ultimately shallow experiences, but Sine Mora isn't one of them.  This is a full package of outstanding quality, hands down one of the best side-scrolling shooters I have played in years, and one that can be enjoyed regardless of skill level. If you're a fan of bullet-hell shooters or ever wanted to be, then this is something you should definitely be checking out!

Sine Mora is exactly what you'd expect from a bullet hell game made in the 10s. Wonderful graphics, a terrific storyline laden with sorrow and grief (I MEAN it) and a polished, well-made feel to it. As a graphic designer, I can say that the whole game exhales good taste, from the menus and interfaces to the choice of using the voice acting in the original language of the developers (hungarian), which just adds to the whole experience. Expect huge bosses, hundreds of power-ups (but no leveling system) and lots of noise from all the explosions and destruction. Pay close attention to insta-kill gimmicks, for they might catch you offguard.

This is one hell of a shoot-em-up.  Think R-Type with a little bit of Starfox. The world and characters are very well-crafted, although the story was a bit hard to follow- time travel plays a big part, and well... it's time travel.  The game truly shines in its art direction.  The environments, aircraft, and enemies are beautifully designed.  Although I would've expected it to be a problem, enemy bullets are highly visible and only manage to blend into the background a little during the prequel mission, which doesn't really count.  Every stage of the game has its own style and character, and often employs appropriate environmental hazards.  Difficulty is reasonably paced- a modest challenge in story mode ranging to reasonably merciless in arcade mode.  Overall, an extremely fun and aesthetically pleasing game executed with solid consistency.  Most certainly the sort of game that will keep me coming back for more.

Sine Mora is a side scrolling bullet eater that looks as gorgeous as it plays. It handles like a dream, and challenges you while never feeling like it's unbeatable. Each time you play you get a little bit better, and last a little bit longer.
What might be the biggest shock in the game is the actual story. With characters that seem like cute animals talking in gibberish language, you might expect a plot similar to StarFox, yet the text boxes that accompany the action often depict the horrible consequences of war and touch on some of the darkest subject matter of any game you may have played before.
It all combines to make Sine Mora a unique, engaging game. Take the chance, play this game and you won't regret it.

The only modern bullet hell shooter that stands out. The kind of game the Japanese would have strived to make if they stayed on the path of fantasy robotics instead of basing every game around annoying school girls. The boss fights are the highlight as they are frequent, have their unique styles, vary in their attack patterns and weapons but the aircrafts, backgrounds and level designs also deserve some praise. Story is short and sweet as it fits in between the levels, spoken by anthropomorphic characters that don't look like they belong on a Saturday morning cartoon and what they have to say really sets the scene. It is short enough to finish in one setting which makes it all the more replayable and although it isn't annoyingly hard to complete it is just as challenging as any other bullet hell if you care about scores.

Sine Mora is a throwback to classic side scrolling shoot em up games, albeit with something of twist in how there is no health, rather there is a timer and each time your plane is hit you lose time. The graphics and backgrounds are visually stunning and beautifully rendered, the music is fairly decent, and there is pretty much no learning curve to the basic controls.\nThe story is pretty complex for a shoot em up and I'm still not entirely certain that I have it figured out. Of course it doesn't help that there is no English audio track, the dialog is still in the original Hungarian.\nThe game's difficulty quickly escalates once you make it past Stage III or so, and it is relentless. It is a challenging difficulty that can frustrate players to either give up on the game entirely or try the level again with a vengeance. It really requires players to become familiar with the game's power ups and time manipulation mechanics. Definitely worth trying out.

Go play Ikaruga when it inevitably comes out on Steam, Jamestown, or Ether instead.

TL:DR; a bad SHMUP for people with a hungarian furry-fetish.

But as much as I would normally say that this is a bad thing Sine Mora uses this to its advantage, as previously said this game is absolutely ball busting hard even on the lowest difficulty and I don't even want to go in to how hard the highest is. The achievements you can get in this game as well reflective this difficulty making it all the more satisfying when you get those achievements and succeed in get the higher ranks in a stage. The gameplay is your basic SHUMP with your upgradable weaponry and visually stunning super moves to help clear the screen or do more damage. The thing that sets Sine Mora apart from the others is its ability to manipulate time allowing you to dodge barrage of bullets easier as well as think your next step or two ahead of time. The game also has not only spectacular visual that engross you as well as some amazing music to accompy you. The game also offers some amazing boss fights and some decent variety in patterns of its bullets requiring some fancy flying. The story however can be a bit confusing and distracting as the entire cast of what might as well be an adult version of the star fox team speak in a different language and requires the player to read the subtitles to understand the story (which is no problem personally for me). But for a SHUMP the story is very complex and does have some interesting characters to go with it.\nOverall Sine Mora is a great example of a modern SHUMP that neither sacrifice story for graphics or graphics for story and is a good buy for both hardcore SHUMP fans and those interested in getting into the series as long as you’re ready to get your reproduction organs smash to bits.

Let me preface this by stating that I am no stranger to intentionally difficult games; that I have over 500 hours logged in the Souls Series; and that I am familiar with and have played several bullet-hell style games.

The Pros
The art in this game is absolutely fantastic, with it's own unique style, it makes everything interesting to look at, even the small trees and shrubs you pass by.
The Bullet-Hell implementation of this game reminds me of the classic Gradius 3 for Super Nintendo that I often played growing up, however, it is unique enough in atmosphere and level design that it is completely its own.
Price. For $10, the devs have clearly understood that this game is SHORT and that they aren't expected to have released particularly much.
The Cons
While the art in this game is incredibly well done, there was constant texture flickering throughout the entire game, making it difficult to play for very long without getting a headache. No, the flickering was not on one thing or another, it was all over the place. In the background, in the foreground, all over foliage, on almost every partially-transparent texture. It was horrendous.
Plot, or rather, the significant lack of plot. The story telling in this game is extremely convoluted and difficult to grasp, with the majority of it conveyed as walls of text between levels. Much isn't explained, everything from the player's motivation for the entire first half of the game, to how an anthropomorphic Buffalo fathered an anthropomorphic Cheetah.
